MC: In the context of this chapter, what is machine learning primarily about?

column3: Writing programs with more loops and conditionals
Extracting knowledge or patterns from data to make predictions or decisions
Encrypting data so it can be stored securely
Converting Python code into faster C code

MC: MC
Which scenario is the clearest example of supervised learning?

column3: Grouping players into play styles" without labels"
Finding unusual logins by clustering user behavior
Predicting whether an email is spam using labeled examples (spam / not spam)
Compressing images using dimensionality reduction without labels

MC: MC
In the chapter's notation, what does X usually represent?

column3: The input features (the measured attributes used to make predictions)
The predicted labels produced by a trained model
The final evaluation score of a model
The random seed used to shuffle a dataset

MC: MC
In the chapter's notation, what does y usually represent?

column3: The number of features in the dataset
The rows of the dataset before shuffling
The algorithm's hyperparameters
The target values / labels the model is trying to learn

MC: MC
Which statement best describes why we split data into training and test sets?

column3: To make the program run faster during training
To increase the number of samples in the dataset
To evaluate how well a model generalizes to unseen data
To ensure the dataset contains only numeric values

MC: MC
What does generalization" mean in machine learning?"

column3: The ability of Python code to run on multiple operating systems
The ability of a model to perform well on new, unseen data
The ability of a dataset to include many columns
The ability of an algorithm to memorize training examples

MC: MC
Why is evaluating a model on the same data used to train it problematic?

column3: It always produces an accuracy of exactly 50%
It prevents the use of scikit-learn
It makes the dataset too small to be useful
It can give an overly optimistic estimate of performance

MC: MC
In scikit-learn, what does the method name fit() mean?

column3: It prints the dataset in a nicely formatted table
It removes missing values from the dataset
It learns model parameters from the training data
It converts the model into a visualization

MC: MC
In scikit-learn, which method is typically used to make predictions on new data after training?

column3: predict()
fit()
score()
split()

MC: MC
What is the purpose of the random_state argument in train/test splitting?

column3: It increases the size of the training set automatically
It makes the split reproducible so results can be repeated
It forces the model to be random during training
It prevents the dataset from being shuffled

pandas

Which statement best describes NumPy in the chapter's tool set?

A library that replaces Python entirely

What is a feature" in a machine learning dataset?"

column3: The name of the dataset file
An individual measurable property/attribute used as an input to the model
The final accuracy score of the model
A plotting style used in matplotlib

In the Iris dataset example used in many introductory workflows, what is the learning task most commonly demonstrated?

column3: Predicting a continuous numeric value from text
Classifying the species of an iris flower from measurements
Clustering game titles by publisher without labels
Compressing images without any labels

In a typical dataset representation, rows (samples) and columns (features) correspond to which shapes?

column3: X is 1D and y is 2D
X is 3D and y is 3D
X is usually 2D (n_samples Ã— n_features) and y is usually 1D (n_samples)
X is a single number and y is always a string

MC: MC
Which of the following best describes classification (as introduced in this chapter)?

column3: Predicting a discrete category label (for example, class A vs class B)
Predicting a continuous numeric value (for example, price)
Finding groups in data without labels
Reducing the number of features without losing information

MC: MC
Which of the following best describes regression (as introduced in this chapter)?

column3: Predicting a category label from images
Grouping customers into clusters without labels
Counting the number of columns in a dataset
Predicting a continuous numeric value (for example, temperature)

MC: MC
What does the k" in k-nearest neighbors refer to?"

column3: The number of features in the dataset
The number of nearest training points used to make a prediction
The number of classes in the dataset
The number of times the model is trained

MC: MC
Why does the chapter emphasize inspecting or visualizing data before modeling?

column3: Because models cannot train without plots
Because visualization automatically improves accuracy
Because it helps detect structure, scale issues, and potential problems early
Because it converts categorical variables into numeric variables

MC: MC
A key limitation of plotting for understanding datasets is:

column3: Plots only work with categorical data
Plots are always inaccurate representations of data
Many datasets have more dimensions than can be directly visualized
Plots prevent the use of train/test splitting

MC: MC
In an introductory workflow, why is a simple baseline model useful?

column3: It provides a reference point to compare more complex models against
It guarantees the best possible accuracy
It removes the need to evaluate performance
It eliminates the need for any data preprocessing

MC: MC
When a model performs very well on training data but poorly on test data, this is most consistent with:

column3: Underfitting
Correct generalization
Overfitting
Data encryption

MC: MC
Which statement best summarizes the role of the test set" in this chapter's workflow?"

column3: It is used to choose feature names and column labels
It is held out during training and used for an unbiased evaluation of performance
It is used to make the training set larger
It is used to shuffle the dataset repeatedly until accuracy improves
